qas.question: What Prussian system was superior to the French example?
Prussian military officers were trained to exude what type thinking?
What commander of the General Staff held the expectaion of independent thinking in his officers?
What did the French dearth of an education and promotion system stifle?
Which military historian criticized the French system as being defective?

context: In addition, the Prussian <a0_0>military education<a0_0/> system was superior to the French model; Prussian staff officers were trained to exhibit initiative and <a1_0>independent thinking<a1_0/>. Indeed, this was <a2_0>Moltke<a2_0/>'s expectation. The French, meanwhile, suffered from an education and promotion system that stifled <a3_0>intellectual development<a3_0/>. According to the military historian <a4_0>Dallas Irvine<a4_0/>, the system "was almost completely effective in excluding the army's brain power from the staff and high command. To the resulting lack of intelligence at the top can be ascribed all the inexcusable defects of French military policy."
